results.title: Richard II
results.creator_credit: David Giles, Cedric Messina, BBC and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description: A BBC production of Shakespeare’s “King Richard the Second” featuring Derek Jacobi as Richard the Second, Sir John Gielgud as Richard of Gaut and Wendy Hiller as the Duchess of York. One of thirty-seven plays by Shakespeare to be presented by the BBC over a six year period.

results.title: Rice in Todays World
results.brief_description: This film focuses on the importance of rice as a major rice crop of the world, focusing on rice-producing areas such as the Orient. Factors contributing to rice growing, such as proper climate, water supply terrain are addressed and this work also contains an overview of the processes in the culture of rice.

results.title: Rice Farming [COLOUR]
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Classroom film on the Australian rice industry: rice growing in Murrumbidgee irrigation area; preparation of the fields; mechanised sowing in the spring; subsequent flooding of paddy fields until harvesting seven months later; harvesting the crop yielding fifty bags to the acre; complementary crops grown on rice farms during winter; milling processes including sifting, removing full, polishing and bagging at local mills. Half the annual rice crop satisfies the home market; the remainder is exported principally in unpolished form.

results.title: Rhythm of a city
results.brief_description:
The first of the pioneer wildlife documentarist’s films to gain wide recognition, this film poem is built on incident and observation evoking without commentary, the rhythm of life in a city (Stockholm) ‘where the fittest survive’.
Won an American Academy Award in 1949.

results.title: Rhythm in paint (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Eliot O'Hara and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Explains that rhythm begins with a thought in writing and a motif in music and painting. Eliot O’Hara and Margaret Shepher show how rhythmic patterns in painting are created, starting with a line, a curve or an angle. Depicts rhythm and its creative function in the artist’s treatment of a chosen motif. Choreography and dancing by Patricia Kaye.

results.title: Rhythm in music
results.brief_description: Using simple musical instruments, a teacher explains to elementary school children the significance of rhythm and accent. Shows how rhythm is found within the individual, within his environment, and in music. Points out the variations in rhythm by accenting beats and by using longer and shorter beats. Shows also how melodies and rhythm are dependent on each other for support to culminate in music.

results.title: Rhythm in athletics
results.brief_description: This film is designed to stimulate interest in, and appreciation of, all types of track and field events. It aims to motivate pupils in athletics where the rhythm and beauty of the activities predominate, without emphasis on competition. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Rewards and reinforcements
results.creator_credit: Robert E. Gilbert, Lee Myerson and Kismet Films
results.brief_description: Economically underprivileged children must often be provided with motives for learning. Because the value system of these children may differ from that of the economically satisfied child, behaviour may need to be reinforced with rewards such as sweets, money, clothes, or other material objects. This principle of reinforcement is based on the operant conditioning theory and involves the application of immediate rewards to shape gradually more difficult tasks.
